commentBody: Three and a half hours before this puzzle came out, one of my friends texted the group chat, ‚ÄúIn XOXO, is x the hug or the kiss?‚Äù Weird timing!
That was so sweet, Kareem!

I am ETERNALLY grateful that I did not have to DWELL on this puzzle for too long, nor look EXTERNALLY for answers, allowing me to DO WELL and keep my gold star streak going.

XOXO

XOXO to this fun puzzle!

And now‚Ä¶

If you want to DO WELL in life, DWELL on the positives.

The victorious sportsball team got many SHOUT OUTS for their back to back SHUT OUTS.

Our Captain Q always CLAMS UP (shudder) whenever any kind of CLAM SOUP is mentioned.

The FLAMINGO has a FLAMING color, seems obvious now that you point it out.

A cute Valentine themed puzzle, with a well worked theme. Not the hardest or trickiest Thursday ever, but fun.  I‚Äôm not going to get SALTY about it.  I balked at LISTEE, but I checked and it is a word. I liked the clever use of punctuation in the clue for ORELSE and enjoyed the clue for GUM (brought back memories of my school days). 

WAWA, our eastern PA convenience store chain was a gimme, headquartered in nearby Wawa, PA, home of WAWA University, where one can learn the seven rules of slicing, the five day dairy ordering system and the seven day deli ordering system.

Good puzzle.  I got STEAL A KISS quickly enough to catch onto the theme early which helped.  Lots of hints that were just the right amount of misleading to make it feel great to figure it out.

Center north was the toughest part for me.  I was so focused on the O in OUTS being the missing O that it took me forever to think of SHUTOUTS.  And GUAM/INCA/ACURA/GIS was a compound Natick for me.  In addition to confusing myself over MATED because I didn't think of "Beat in chess" as a past tense form.

Loved it. I‚Äôm the guy who never gets the trick on Thursday. I tirelessly solve from the crosses and then read the column to learn what I have missed. Not today! Charming puzzle where it was fun to sort out the theme answers. 

What? Wait? This had something to do with Valentine‚Äôs Day? 

Sigh.

Maybe next week.
Once again solved without getting the gimmick. I  had to laugh when I read it was a Valentines Day themed puzzle. That seems even crazier.
Very sweet and fun. Thank you!
Cute!

Terrific puzzle, jam packed with theme material, most of it pretty stellar‚ÄîI especially loved CLAMS(O)UP.  As Kareem said, it‚Äôs hard to build a grid like this and have decent fill, and I think he succeeded. Maybe LISTEE a little clunky but nothing much else stood out.  Notice a double stack of ten letter entries‚Äîthat‚Äôs very unusual with this much theme material. TIL about BATISTE; some may find LANCET a little obscure but it was a gimme for me and the name of a prestigious British medical journal. Overall I personally figured out the theme and got through it pretty quickly, but found it interesting and delightful, and I enjoyed trying to figure out the theme entries once I got the trick. Thanks for a great Valentine, Kareem!
Best Thursday in a long time. Nice! XO

Cute. Very easy and still fun. It often makes Thursdays easier if I figure out what the trick is first. Today, it was then no challenge to solving the eight starred clues.

XXX OOO to the constructor. üòòü§ó
It took me a long time to figure out the Trick, but in the end it was fun!  With 8 words encrypted, the difficulty of the crosses was just right.

Lots to love here!  

-10 theme answers (5 are across and 5 that are down)
-all of the theme answers are still words with or without the x/o
-the symmetry of taking away the X yet adding the O

Great work!
That was delightful! xoxo
Liked the theme... but NE took me a bit to crack and the LISTEE / SEE intersection was a little sticky for me.  I loved that PANTERA was in the puzzle as I was listening to my new Deftones vinyl.

I in vain wish they would‚Äôve done something with pianist Jon BATISTE with 48-Across. I‚Äôd never heard of the fabric. 66-Across really tripped me up because I thought it would for sure be MAniS, especially with the M, A, and S in place. Sadly, that was not the case.

Also, if you changed ‚ÄúIBEX‚Äù to ‚ÄúapEX‚Äù and changed ‚ÄúLANCET‚Äù to ‚ÄúLANCES‚Äù, I feel like that would be a lot easier to clue? Maybe that‚Äôs just me. And it would work with the downs too!

Impressive! I really enjoyed my late night tussle with this beauty. 8 theme answers plus 2 revealers stuffed into a weekday grid? Just Wow! 
 
The simplest clues can trip me up - on any day of the week. Today I fell for ‚ÄúBeat at chess‚Äù  which has to be ‚ÄôMATE‚Äô. It doesn‚Äôt fit so you start making thongs up - 
 Could it refer to a Chess pie? What else can ‚ÄòBeat‚Äô mean? BUT IT‚ÄôS CHESS!! What on earth is going on?!! And then, Duhhh! In the end finished about average. Some toughies, some gimmes, some TIL.  Perfect Thursday. 

Happy Valentine‚Äôs Day to all!! 
XOXO to the constructor (Kareem) and the whole Games team!

Just today I brought home some chocolate-covered strawberries and have already started nibbling on them.

I wondered if I was getting ahead of myself, but then along comes this puzzle to assure me that Valentine's Day is February 14, give or take...

Thank you, Mr. Ayas for this super creative puzzle that was a joy to solve!

XOXO to you and the editors and column writers and fellow solvers. ‚ô•Ô∏è!

Excellent puzzle! The theme came slowly at first, then faster and faster - very satisfying to work out during the solve.
I love that OXO was in there like a little bonus, as if there weren't already enough theme words!
Many thanks!

Just got back from three days at Disneyland and I‚Äôm thoroughly wiped out. In The Magic Kingdom I heard lots of little children saying both TEHEE and hEHEE which made for quite a difficult natick with the crossing of BATISTE.

In my delirium I convinced myself mouse ears were made of BATIShE üòµ‚Äçüí´üò¥

I love how the Brits sign their emails/texts with just the x or in case of lots of love, xx or xxx. They do kisses we do hugs. Brits feel free to correct me or add context!

tl;dr    Great puzzle, one that really kicked my behind in terms of misadventures, but also one I was proud to have finally gotten.

I'm going to say it, and say it boldly.

This one really wrung me through the ringer.  I can't remember the last time a Thursday took me so long.

It might have been easy for others, but even after I figured out it involved removing "O"s and inserting "X"s, I still couldn't quite make it all work.

One critical mistake I made was to put the X in 11D in the wrong place, and wow did that make things confusing.  I could have saved myself from some grief had I realized that the "X-inserted word" would still have to be a real word.

And it didn't help that I was sure that 6A was OAHU.

I haven't read any other comments, but I'm guessing this one is going to be controversial?

Color me impressed with this tricky Thursday grid. I love that you added O but deleted the X for the themers. Then the two revealers crossed each other. And how cute that OXO was in there! 

My grandfather bought an ACURA Legend in 1988, replacing his 1977 Cadillac Coupe DeVille. Yet again, the puzzle brings up a long ago memory ü•∞

Thank you, Kareem!
XOXO

Having look at it further, I'm going to upgrade my opinion about this puzzle from great to superb.

Challenging and a LOT of fun.

Cross my heart.

(Don't believe Andrzej's "Delightful" when it comes.)

@Sam L @The X-Phile @SBK @dutchiris    Here's one for the Mann moot.

Browsing scholarship on the web, there are those who claim The Magic Mountain is a standard Bildungsroman where a young man travels, has various encounters and adventures, and then proceeds to do great deeds. Others argue that Hans goes to the mountain, meets new people with new ideas and learns a lot but then returns home to do what he would have done if he never left.

A third group reads it as another literary clich√© The Hero's Journey.  They focus particularly on a descent to the Underworld of the xray lab where Hans sees his skeleton, (his grave?), and peppers Dr. Behrens with questions about life, death and illness.  (If that's the Underworld, what does that make Dr. B?) 

In Mann's Forward he writes at length about how he is going to tell the story.  He stresses that the story will be uniquely about Hans and that Hans is a perfectly normal person.  He is not the typical protagonist of those genres.

I submit that Mann is mocking those forms.  I'll reply to this with some evidence if and when it clears the emus.
‚ù§Ô∏è this puzzle!

Overcame my fear of those asterisks and made a string of very lucky guesses, but spent forever, DWELLing in the NW corner. Came to the column, raced back to the puzzle, wound it up, now back to the column to GIVE A HUG to Kareem Ayas for an agile puzzle, dodgy and fun to work.  

Thank you, K.A.!
I thought Valentines Day was February 14th.
Solved quickly once I decided that the answers didn‚Äôt need to make sense but had to read the info to fully comprehend the trick

commentBody: Delightful.

Such a fun puzzle! I loved it. Just enough of a challenge that I was tempted to check the grid, but I managed it with no hints (I‚Äôm on a streak, but in all honesty the puzzles must be a little bit easier lately if I‚Äôve made it 18 days). It took me a while to get Guam, even feeling confident that GIs was correct so that too section was the toughest for me. I was pretty chuffed when I got the theme and saw that they were all words with and without their x or o. Thanks for this fun puzzle, Kareem!

The crossed words in this crossword come across as brilliant.  The give/steal craftiness is clever and fun to begin with, but to make every theme answer cross exactly its pair and no other, and the revealer do that too, don't cross words with me because it crosses the line!  I LOVED it. <3
This was a really fun one! I loved how the X and O answers always crossed each other

Surely the ones ‚Äúover there‚Äù are the European allies the GIs are going to aid, not the GIs themselves.

‚ÄúSend the word over there that the Yanks are coming.‚Äù

"G.I." wasn't a term for soldiers when the song, "Over There," was written, or for quite a few years afterward. The song was WW-I era, but "G.I." meaning a soldier only came along in the run-up to the Second World War, in the mid to late 1930's. So, George M. Cohan was not referring to "G.I.s" in his song.
A good crossword. Loved the theme, all the theme entries, the other fill, and the theme's aptness to the Valentine week. Hall of fame 2026.
That was a very clever puzzle.  Tricky and fun!
Great theme and execution. So many theme entries while maintaining pretty smooth fill. I loooooove it :)
But we gave the kisses and stole the hugs? Wouldn‚Äôt ‚ÄúSteal a kiss‚Äù make more sense if we removed the Xs, and ‚ÄúGive a hug‚Äù if we added the Os?
Very good puzzle, thanks

It‚Äôs ironic that the IBEX was saved from extinction by Charles Felix, King of Sardinia, on whose death in 1831 the main line of the House of Savoy itself became extinct. In terms of conservation, he was perhaps the GOAT. 

Wikipedia tells us: 

When firearms spread in the 15th century, the large population of ibex that spanned many of Europe's mountains decreased as they became easy targets for hunters. The ibex was often hunted for its meat, with other body parts used for medicine. The ibex horns were highly sought after as a remedy for impotence, while its blood was used for treating kidney stones.

The relentless hunting of the alpine ibex might have led to its extinction were it not for the foresight of the dukes of Savoy. Charles-Felix, Duke of Savoy and King of Sardinia, banned the hunting of the ibex across his estates of the Gran Paradiso after being persuaded by a report on the animal's endangered state.

Wow, I really put myself in a hole, but was finally able to dig myself out of it.   For 7D and 6A I had the pairing of HERESY and OAHU. I visited the USS Arizona memorial at Oahu, and I thought for certain these were correct.   After solving everything but the NE corner, and banging my head for 10-20 minutes I finally saw the error of my ways and came up with the proper answers for those two, and was finally able to complete that quadrant for the gold star.

Clever, but annoying. I was convinced that ‚Äúgive a hug‚Äù meant that you had actually to add an ‚ÄúO‚Äù to the across answers - ie with a rebus. Wasted 15 minutes trying to work out what I was getting wrong.
What will they think Of neXt?

Great puzzle and lots of fun. If I may be a tad pedantic about one clue... As a French speaker, "four gras" is by definition a p√¢t√© and thus unnecessary within the clue itself. To call it a "p√¢t√© de fois gras" is redundant. Thanks for a pleasant solve.

Fun one!
This was a lovely start to the day and a great distraction from the growing inbox. Hugs and kisses to all XOXO
A particularly good Thursday puzzle! More by this constructor, please

I think delightful has been over-used, so I'll say nicely enjoyable. 

Apart from the couple of clues that were very local - EXETER (incidentally a very pleasant  small city in the south of England), ACURA, oh and I hadn't heard of BATISTE, I gradually solved with lots of crossers.

Love letters indeed. A clever puzzle, thanks, Kareem.

40A, LANCET. Timely for me. We are going to Jacksonville this morning for surgery consultation for my husband. Send me some virtual HUGs.

It doesn't work on my desktop or on my iPhone.

Thanks, guys, for nothing.
Elle King gives, Elle King steals: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0uLI6BnVh6w&list=RD0uLI6BnVh6w&start_radio=1
I never comment but I absolutely loved this theme! My absolute favourite puzzle so far.
Well done!! Very satisfying solve. Got the theme clues quickly but it still took me to the end to figure out how to apply them. Textbook Thursday puzzle.

Well, yes, this was a constructing feat.  Are you kidding me?  Ten theme answers totaling a sky-high 72 squares, with each theme answer working two ways due to the gimmick, crossing revealers, and still the grid has hardly a whiff of junk?

But a constructing feat is shallow, not to mention show-offish, if it doesn‚Äôt deliver satisfaction to the solver.

I can only speak for myself, but this theme was a first-order, multi-level capital-R Riddle, and cracking it brought great fulfillment, the sweet feeling that I earned this.  That, plus being wowed by the feat, well, it also brought a huge inner standing O.

Sticky areas gave my brain pleasure as well.

Truly, a lovely puzzle could have been based on the STEAL A KISS element alone, but Kareem pulled off the double-play, all in a single 15x15 box.  

Hats off on this one.  Bravo, Kareem. Perfecto!  An apex Valentine's Day puzzle.  Can‚Äôt wait for your next, and thank you for a scintillating solve!
Definitely a tough one--well done, and well-constructed.

After a very short period, I got the gimmick for the Across clues. It took a little while longer for the Down ones. But overall, it was a very smooth solve and an amazing construction.

It helped that I did know BATISTE. Do they still make handkerchiefs? (Yuk, how unsanitary!). And that evoked another memory. I'm of the age when hankies were on their way out. A little girl in my kindergarten class, Elizabeth, would come to school every day with a hankie pinned to her dress. She would go up to the other girls and ask if they'd be her friend. We all thought it was creepy, but that was a different, gentler time, and nobody ever bullied her, though we all did avoid her. I can't imagine what that would be like today in our crass and cruel culture. 

One question, though. I have no idea why an O is a symbol for a hug. I would think that ( ) would be more like it.

The only place I've ever seen TEHEE is in the New York Times crossword. It must be common somewhere, no doubt, but it's outside my experience. It seems bizarre to pronounce "te" with a long "e."

I also have to wonder where the word came from in the first place, because I've never heard a laugh that actually sounded like that...but then again, onomatopoeic words tend to vary wildly. Just look at all the words for what a rooster sounds like from various cultures, for instance.

This took me a bit over an hour. Neither East Coast convenience stores nor prep schools have ever been part of my day-to-day existence.

Have I ever heard of batiste? No, I don't think I had, despite having a wardrobe full of paisley handkerchiefs. But they're all that cheap cotton batik kind. The word "batiste" comes from the name of its inventor, the 14th c. Norman weaver Batiste of C(h)ambray, also the source of the words "chambray" and "cambric." Or perhaps not. Perhaps as the fabric was traditionally used for drying the wet foreheads of newly baptized Norman newborns. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c_T7HgZKZjo&list=RDc_T7HgZKZjo&start_radio=1
GIs are WW2. Doughboys are WW1. Over there is a WW1 song
xoxoxo loved it
I forgot to ask - how do phone calls DROP? I've got used to the fairly recent (in the UK at least) use of 'drop' for TV programmes, films, music, fashions and so on, but a phone call?

Ooh, I just figured out the theme and I absolutely love it! Never have I commented on a puzzle before being done with it, but this gave me such a thrill I had to tell someone (haha). Seeing Kareem Ayas' name as I opened the grid got my hopes up, and I am not disappointed! I wish I could draw this out to savor longer, but I'm already halfway completed... This is how my brain feels as I solve this grid. Yippee! https://tenor.com/view/snoop-snoopy-peanuts-dance-dancing-gif-11022999122914157975

OWESTO EXEaTER (almost) leading to a LATEX once you EXIT This is the theme that just keeps giving, and keeps taking away. Jon Batiste is usually the main attraction, but I think Corinne Bailey Rae more than holds her own here. https://youtu.be/7gVpJBTcUK0?si=1UZc0opCsRF70-DG

One of the best puzzles in a while. Very satisfying solve. Great theme. Limited amount of trivia. Ticks all the boxes that I like in a puzzle. And what a construction feat! (that too without showing off!)
Interesting puzzle. Today's earworm brought to you by Rod Stewart https://youtu.be/5w2HnG0YGFA?si=izWUFkQjeZPOzpQw

Yes indeedy, although we refer to all residents of Tawantinsuyu, "the Realm of the Four Parts," as "Inca(n)(s)," the term "Inca" technically refers only to the ruler, and perhaps his extended family. It's as if we referred to all Arabian subjects of the House of Saud as "Saudi Arabians." Oh wait, we do.

Like the Roman Empire and Tsarist Russia, the Inca Empire rose rapidly, expanded broadly, and incorporated many different ethnicities and languages. And all without the use of the wheel, and, indeed, money!
I had trouble because I took the revealer clues literally.  I thought STEAL A KISS meant to take an X away from the answer, and that GIVE A HUG meant add an O to the answer.  Oh, well.

An extremely well-constructed puzzle, with five thematic entries in each orientation, arranged in intersecting pairs! Pretty amazing in fact, especially in light of the quality of the fill in general.

I assume the constructor tried very hard to get a thematic entry in the location occupied by PANTERA rather than DWELL; this would have perfected the construction aesthetically. 

All in all, a masterpiece of construction with a clever theme that was also fun to solve. Bravo!

I thought this was fantastic! Chef's kiss! And Chef's hug! In his final years, my father didn't have much of a memory. He couldn't hold any sort of a conversation and answered every question with yes. He had to be reminded repeatedly to keep eating his meals because he'd forget what he was doing. However, he would often sing old songs I'd never heard before. One was a parody version of "Over There". The lyrics were along the lines of "Over there, over there, I'm staying here until the fighting's over over there." Does anybody here have any recollection of a song like that? And here's an inappropriate song he used to sing only around one of his caregivers, who fortunately took it with good humor. I apologize in advance if anyone's offended. The "Too Fat Polka": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3cn-iPEEzfA

I really liked this one. Really challenging, but everything was doable. Relatively few naticks or crossword crutch answers. Clever theme that took a few minutes to figure out even after getting the revealing clue. Well done!

Now this is what I call a puzzle!!¬† Devilishly conceived, brilliantly executed, and really dense, it created an almost unbearable feeling of curiosity in me before I caught on.¬† When I did catch on -- and only¬†because of the two apt, clever, and in-the-language revealers -- my Aha Moment was huge.¬† The fact that the Acrosses and Downs are doing two different things and also doing them differently was an added delight.¬† And then the fact that the X-added answers and the O-subtracted answers are real words of their own -- what an achievement!!!¬†
¬†
Kudos to Kareem for this.¬† It's going into my running list for Puzzle of the Year and could end up my top choice.¬† Keep 'em coming please, Kareem!

I appreciate the work that goes into constructing this puzzle, and I imagine for people who like gimmicks more than puzzles, this will be a thrill. I found it a pretty miserable solving experience. Convoluted tricks over solid crossword hints and answers always lower its score for me. Pass.

Brilliant puzzle! I marvel at the work it takes to make a puzzle like this, which provides so many of us a few minutes of pleasure each day. I enjoyed catching onto the double trick, which made solving the themed entries enjoyable.
So much fun! Thanks

Tough puzzle for me, but finally tumbling to the trick was a huge turning point and that's always a nice touch. But being able to work in all of those theme answers with those tricks is just amazing. And... that all of theme answers were valid words with or without the trick is also amazing. Three thumbs up. And... my puzzle find today. A Sunday from April 28, 1985 by Jim Page with the title: "Play it by ear." A couple of theme clue and answer examples: "Borg: 6/6/56?" BJORNTOSUCCEED "Abdul-Jabbar to Laker fans?" KAREEMOFTHECROP "What QB Graham signed?" OTTOGRAPHS "Part of Rockne's needle found in the Bard's cauldron?" EYEOFKNUTE And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=4/28/1985&g=66&d=A ....

I thoroughly enjoyed the trick to this Thursday puzzle, but as a military historian I feel compelled to point out a glaring error. 

The clue for 6D refers to the song ‚ÄúOver There,‚Äù published in 1917. The answer to the clue, ‚ÄúGIs,‚Äù while it does refer to American soldiers, saw its first use as a noun in 1943 according to Merriam-Webster. American soldiers in WWI were known as doughboys. They weren‚Äôt called GIs until WWII.
LISTEE could have stayed in 1995.

Perfect Thursday and Valentine's fun! 
On a ferryboat in the late 80's: 
My friend's daughter is chewing gum. 
"Nikki - where did you get the gum?" 
"Under the table!" 
EEEEeeewwwww!

Hi all. Sorry I‚Äôm slow to the draw in answering your nice comments. Thank you @tracy @francis. @jerry to answer your question about my poems. My poem is compsed of words found in the clues and answers and is always 3 parts ‚Ä¶. a/ across clues ; d/ down clues ; a/ answers. My rule is i can only use words found in those parts of the puzzle for those corresponding parts of the poem. Here is today‚Äôs poem

public messages

a/ the sign on the restroom: surrender the cat
surrender?‚Ä¶.
it‚Äôs a heavy cat
i take a measurement
it‚Äôs heavy
i take the cat out
it‚Äôs sunny. i smoke.
must i comfort the cat?
d/ (appearing befuddled)
i might a/ hug it
or give it a mouse

Lovely crunchy Thursday. Thanks Kareem!

Super fun theme. But I was absolutely flummoxed by that NE block with ACURA, OR ELSE, GUAM, and INCA. 

Something about the clues for those was just completely obtuse to me, and went straight over my head. Just couldn‚Äôt get a toehold. Even LADDERS didn‚Äôt click until I lucked out with MATED.

Very fun overall, but man that whole section felt rough for a Thursday.
I agree this is another case where crosswords miseducate people. In addition to what you & the other solver mentioned about Vietnam era, the song "Over There" refers to soldiers as "Yanks", not GIs.

It is simply the case that some of us like crossword puzzles where the idea is to find the words that meet the definitions; and some also like some gimmick that sacrifices the integrity of the noble grid for the benefit of some wordplay or pun. 
I like to think of myself as in the latter group, but the gimmicks have to be both clever and reasonably understandable from the clues. 
In my view there is simply no reason for me to think that "steal a kiss" means "the referenced words have an X that shouldn't be there but put it there anyway." It's not as though there is some existing cultural reference point. To steal a kiss is indeed a thing, and an X as a signoff kiss is indeed a thing, but putting the two together is like saying that dogs have fleas and schoolchildren like to flee after school, so ... I don't know, maybe the dogs should scratch the kids. 
I am therefore with heavy heart tendering my resignation from all crossword solving with the New York Times. Having given this decision a great deal of thought, it is final and I will not yield to any coercion or inducement. That is my final word, a personal ban on doing the crossword for the entire rest of the day. 
I'll see y'all tomorrow. XOXO
I love Thursday crosswords. The ones that are a puzzle-within-a-puzzle. And my favorite kinds are the ones where rebus/theme answers result in other valid words or phrases. So this was a great one.
No notes, this is a great puzzle, really pleasant fill. Thank you.

Puzzle within a puzzle? Check.
Fun theme? Check.
Brilliant clues that are also challenging? Check.
Clever Easter egg (OXO)? Check.
Aha moment after aha moment? Check!

This one checks all the boxes. Or to put it another way, I‚Äôve been checkMATED.

Another late puzzle find. A Monday from October 6, 2014 by Robyn Weintraub. Four theme answers, straightforwardly clued:

LYINEYES
SIGNININTHERAIN
PUTTINONTHERITZ
MOVINOUT 

And then the... 'reveal' across the center or the puzzle: 

"Lost... or in two words, an apt description of 17-, 24-, 47- and 59-across"
MISSING

Here's that link: 

....
Wow! What a fun puzzle!
This one was a lot of fun! I‚Äôll be giggling about the UNHOLY Biblical AXMEN all day!

XOXO to this puzzle! Mwah! Absolutely loved the theme, and I'm in awe at the skill and creativity in its construction. Bonus that the stolen X's and given O's resulted in real words. A very satisfying Thursday!
Also, PANTERA mentioned üôåüèº

I just hate Thursday puzzles. I keep saying I will skip them, but here I am. I don't always mind the wordplay aspect (though I usually respond to the solve with an eyeball)-- it's the part about using the rebus key the way it's intended to fill the grid. Even though I've solved the wordplay I get an error message and cannot usually figure out how to fill it so that I don't break my streak by using "reveal". I just don't find them fun.

TIL: Batiste is a fabric! Had no idea.
Another terrific puzzle from Kareem, one of my favorite constructors.

I loved this solve. My only problem may have been that it was a bit too easy. Beat my Thursday average by several minutes. I got the missing o, part right away, but I solved 95% of the puzzle before I realized that we also added x's to some of the down answers.

Good puzzle
Crossing Tehee (odd spelling) with keel is a bit of a kick in the shins.

I guess I should have joined the Yale online boat club during the pandemic.
What a fabulous puzzle!!
A fun puzzle, but the themes seemed reversed to me. I would expect words relating to "stealing a kiss" to be missing letters, and words that are being "given a hug" to have extra. Is it just me?
Best theme execution in while, screamed through most of the fill but hit a mental block in the northeast corner. Gritted through to steal the gold star! Nicely done
Fantastic puzzle.  So fun when I figured out the X and O 'trick'.

That was pretty dope! Thankful that I was not trying this puzzle alone.

SHOUTOUT to RADIANS, the best measure of angles
A lot fun! Loved it!

I never do well with Thursdays which means I often hate Thursdays.  But today I caught the trick and got a gold star.  Yes, I'm posting this just to congratulate myself.

I almost lost it with 11D -- where's the X?  But a typo was my mistake, and when it went away, the X slipped right in 

Yay me.

very cute. loved it. 

thank you for the lack of a rebus!
How cute (groan).

I thought today was Tuesday, and spent the whole puzzle wondering why it felt like a Thursday. I was so confused! It was surely a moral outrage!

No, I just hadn‚Äôt taken my Ritalin. The weird thing is, I still finished under my Tuesday time limit. So‚Ä¶I had the power all along?
a Thursday classic thanks Kareem! this is why we do Xwords!

This was fun. 

A little quick for me on a Thursday at 20m, but the theme was clever and enjoyable to suss out.

I am guessing a lot of the comments are positive today.

Quick one. I was half way through the Down clues before it hit me that the revealers were not telling me what had been done to the themers, but what I had to do to them. After that, I had fun doing it. Mentally, anyway.
I liked it!

Fun theme today. When I was a kid, I was always confused why Xes were kisses and Os were hugs, because X looks like a person opening their arms to give a hug, and O looks like a person's mouth giving a kiss.

As an added personal challenge I decided to attempt today‚Äôs puzzle whilst bound in a straitjacket and suspended upside down over the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.  I‚Äôll spare details, but needless to say after 6 hours and an NYPD airlift across the Upper Bay, this wasn‚Äôt a personal best for me brahs.
The Vermont Country Store catalog offers batiste sleepwear for men and women, and ladies' slips. You do know what a slip is, of course.
Can anyone recall the last rebus Thursday offered. Seems as if it has been a while. Nice twist today. But it seems as though the hugs were stolen(missing O‚Äôs)  and the kisses were added?
Fabulous work. Thank you Kareem!

Am I the only one for whom the ‚ÄúSort by: Oldest‚Äù option has been re-activated? It‚Äôs a little odd to see all the nesting turned inside-out, the words written bottom to top in ‚Äòredro esrever‚Äô, and the first  ‚Äòoldest‚Äô post being from 2015. But at least we get something for our click.


Oh wait - now it‚Äôs not working again.

From the looks of it, this is a more contrarian view, but this didnt entirely do it for me. The theme was great, but even after cracking it, it took a bit too long for things to fall into place for me. Maybe just not my day, but INCA, PANTERA and IBEX were all big struggles- and one too many clues that a Brit like me would struggle with (GUAM, WAWA and EXETER needed the crossing clues to get there). Still a good puzzle but fried me a bit I have to say!
Quite clean, super fun. Loved it!
Challenging but still accessible for me. It was fun once I saw the X and O theme. Thanks Kareem ‚ù§Ô∏è

The fill was fine, Kareem! As soon as I solved the theme in the NW corner, the puzzle fell immediately. 

Fun puzzle!

Okay, I enjoyed this puzzle to the same degree that I dislike the new comments format. TEHEE. 

Really a fun one! I knew something was up for sure at FLAMING but wasn't sure what... rebus? Maybe, don't know, so I focused on getting the revealers. I still wasn't sure if we were supposed to give or steal the hugs and kisses in rebus or not, so I just left some blanks to come back them. After a bit, I just clicked on each revealer to examine them with their shaded counterparts, and then the aha arrived! I'm literally having to try so hard to not type the word delightful now, but it genuinely is the word coming to me...  Har! 

I came in slower than normal and found the upper left to be very tricky for me, and had a few missteps that others had, like oahu instead of GUAM, for example. But I never CEDEd and I maintained an even KEEL, so overall, I think did DWELL in it! 

Really a fun one!

This one is for the early adopters, those who press the Refresh button at exactly 10 PM Eastern to get the next fix.  I've been trying to join that club but, alas, my brain by that time of the night is not up to the job.  

I consider myself a fairly intelligent and educated fellow but the skill needed to nail these grids has as much to do with biochemistry as anything else.  

So I will probably remain a morning person.  

See y'all tomorrow.
Fun and pretty fresh

I am woefully weak on WW II monuments, or I would have realized that OAHU was not right.  After stepping away and returning later I realized the down was probably GIS and that triggered GUAM‚Ä¶ Boy I wish I had solved those sooner!
I am shocked, shocked I tell you, that YOKO ONO or a variant was not in this puzzle.
Wow. Brilliant puzzle. Loved it.
Perfectly attuned to what I'm able to do with crosswords, it was a real pleasure!
üëé

As I was starting this puzzle, I wondered if there might be any fun love-themed ones coming up over the next couple days... what a delight to realize that this was one! 

I know Valentine's Day isn't everyone's cup of tea, but I admittedly have always loved it, since I was a child- the idea of celebrating love, in whatever form it takes- just lights me up and feels good.
Until I knew the theme, I thought "latex" was a deadbeat dad.

I've graduated to doing Thursday puzzles now with autocheck so they are always a challenge. But I never would have figured this one out and can appreciate now knowing why the answers didn't make sense. Very clever if not frustrating.
This puzzle really should have accepted rebus entries (letter + O) for the squares in the "give a hug" themed clues. It took me way too long to realize that was why the puzzle wouldn't end.

Very fun and challenging even though I got the revealers   quickly and figured out what they meant. Today is my birthday and I enjoyed coming back to the puzzle throughout the day until it finally came together.
Really enjoyed this one.  Clever theme and challenging cluing.  Perfect for a Thursday.   Thanks for the fun!

This one was so fun! I was slowly filling the theme squares but could not get the trick until it finally hit me and I filled the rest in with ease. Let out a cry of appreciation when I got it--bravo to the constructor. Very enjoyable.

To "take out" is not to "see". Does "I'm taking Patricia out to dinner" mean the same thing as "I'm seeing Patricia"? Absolutely not!

And can someone please tell me what a "listee" is.
Nice one. I got stuck in a KENEL(s) thinking that it would be more explicitly plural despite knowing it was misspelled. A bad oMEN indeed.

@Barry Ancona when I solve a puzzle ‚Äúthe night before‚Äú as I have done tonight, you are almost always one of the first comments. It must be a big part of your day to be here at the moment the puzzle drops. I enjoy it when I can make it fit. I find myself making it more of a game with myself to focus and get it done, then, as quickly as possible.

I was confused a few months ago when I was the first one ‚Äúhere‚Äú to post a comment on a Thursday, Friday or Saturday. I‚Äôm nowhere near the fastest solver. As fast as I thought I was, I‚Äôm not in the top 20%. Perhaps there was a glitch with the system that night.

Anyway, I enjoy the three puzzles a week that I do and I enjoy reading the comments. I have gone back now in the archives five or six years. It goes faster because I only do those three days a week.

I enjoy reading your comments. Have a good weekend.

@Cat Lady Margaret

We've had SHOCKING PINK, but FLAMING pink is just as shocking.

@Chris
"Beat" as a past and "Digs" as a singular both tripped me up for a bit!

@Chris

Get out of my brain! I had the exact same experience. I also thought I‚Äôd have to do a lookup to gain a toehold in that north section, but then OR ELSE came to me, which led to OLDER, which made me realize ‚Äúoh, it‚Äôs the *other* O!‚Äù and then I was off and running. So much fun.

@Al  in Pittsburgh

It took me a while to understand the theme. I also thought of OAHU.

@Al  in Pittsburgh

Happy to hear that!

@SP finally got to it just now, and such fun! I was surprised when BATISTE came to my mind immediately, bc I wasn't sure what it was and didn't think it could be right the first time through. But must have been from my historical fiction reading days in elementary school-- all those handkerchiefs. It's so funny to me how sometimes words jump out like that, minus the definition, then turn out to be correct.

My favorite example might be funny for you-- years ago I had a kid come in very flushed, mild tachycardia, started feeling uncomfortable after dinner the night before. I asked what they'd eaten-- salmon. The word "scombroid" popped into my head. I vaguely recalled it might be a type of food poisoning but no details came attached with the word! 

So I told the mom and the med student with me that I had just thought of something but needed to look it up.  I never try to fake pts out... I just say when I don't know. We didn't have computers in the rooms back then. Anyway, bingo, it was classic Scombroid toxin poisoning! His mom had thawed the salmon on the counter. None of my colleagues at the med school had heard of it.

Never saw it again in 30 yrs of practice. Gave him a dose of Benadryl and fixed him right up.

userLocation: US rules: Don't get sick. Don't get old.
commentBody:
@dutchiris
Glad to hear from you in whatever circumstances. Yes, it's harder to storm through the days sweeping all, or at least most, before you. But as Mr Donne almost wrote, mine age asks ease, and sometimes will brook no denial. 
So if I start out the day striding imperiously down the almost walkable sidewalks, I'm allowed to grab a nap after walking the grocery cart home and getting it all unpacked into freezer, fridge, drawers and cupboards. 
I'm a night owl and I'll be up and puzzling in the wee hours. As they wisely say in these tautological days, you do you. Keep pushing as far as you can. We're all watching the world teeter in the hands of idiots but don't miss a step for that.

@Al  in Pittsburgh     some supporting quotes

In the At Thielemann's section Mann says:

‚Äúa man who is capable of achievement over and above the average and expected modicum must be equipped either with a moral remoteness and single- mindedness which is rare indeed and of heroic mould, or else with an exceptionally robust vitality. Hans Castorp had neither the one nor the other of these; and thus he must be considered mediocre, though in an entirely honourable sense.‚Äù

Settembrini often speaks for Mann.  He describes the citizens of Hamburg as ‚ÄúA Phlegmatic and Energetic people‚Äù The phlegmatic temperment is calm, introverted, resistant to change, and service-oriented.  One not well suited to great deeds.  Cousin Joachim says: ‚ÄúThe best thing is to have no opinions and do one's duty.

When Settembrini attempts to get Hans to leave the Berghof he says: ‚ÄúThis is the island of Circe and you are no Oddyseus.‚Äù

Is it surprising that Hans will return to Hamburg and do what any Burgher with good manners would do?

@Al  in Pittsburgh

Oops.  I forgot to add one citation from serious academic scholarship.

From yale.edu/modernismlab/the-magic-mountain   by Klara Schubenz
‚Üë ‚ÄúThat ‚ÄòThe Magic Mountain‚Äô parodies a host of literary genres and conventions is finely obvious.‚Äù, is already stated by Harold Boom in his introduction to: Thomas Mann‚Äôs The Magic Mountain. Ed. Harold Bloom. New York: Chelsea House Publishers, 1986, p. 1. 
‚ÄúAlthough Hans learns a lot, it ultimately remains highly doubtful whether Hans has learned enough and whether he turns into a ‚Äòproductive‚Äô member of society or not, considering the fact that he leaves the sanatorium only to join the war.‚Äù
And go Gunners!

commentBody:
@SBK

Yeah, but "won't" is future, and they weren't there yet.
@pmom In order for the words to make sense, you have to "steal a kiss" (remove the X) or "give a hug" (add an O)

@Petrol
Perhaps C-F shared a certain sympathy for creatures with the letter X in their name--a trait which he picked up from his Grandmother, Polyxena of Hesse-Rotenburg. He was very fond of lynxes and oryxes as well, and did much to preserve native habitat of the axolotl. While in Mexico, he adopted a pair of xoloitzcuintli from a local shelter, which he kept with him at all times, even taking them, in 1794, on his campaign in Morgex.

commentBody: @Andrzej This is a hilarious and irreverent vignette of arcane European history - clearly your work!

I did have to look up Xoloitzcuintle - i learned that it is a Mexican hairless dog, thought to have travelled into the Americas with the settlers who came from Siberia all those many eons ago. I look forward to this word turning up in a Sunday grid sometime!
@Bill Thanks!  xoloitzcuintli is my new password

userLocation: Ridin' the big D of delight
commentBody:
@RozzieGrandma

Like many of the early saints, he wasn't officially sainted - he's just *considered* a saint. He probably never existed, anyway. Have you heard of St. Vilgefortis? The crucified bearded lady? There is a theory that she arose out of the misinterpretation of unusually robed figures of the crucified Christ. The stuff one learns traveling around Europe, eh?

@Andrzej
St. Vilgefortis, or at least the study of her legend, plays a role in the novel *Fifth Business*, first volume of the Depford Trilogy, by one of my favorite writers, the Canadian novelist Robertson Davies.

@Bill

He also was a big fan of the LA band "X" (especially Exene Cervenka) and was a HUGE X-phile. #Facts

Handkerchiefs persist, despite the onslaught of kleenex. (Pluralisation alert: kleenices?) Partly as a waste reduction measure, partly as (still!) a sign of gentility, handkerchiefs continue to be made and used. Cheap cotton more than silk but still out there.

You don't believe I'm sinking, look what a hole I'm in."

@Bruce Well, it's in the dictionary... https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/tehee And although "teehee" is more common, TEHEE isn't unused: https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=tehee%2Cteehee&year_start=1800&year_end=2022&corpus=en&smoothing=3

@Bruce I don't like TEHEE either. Or "tepee." Definitely crosswordese in my opinion. But these are words you learn to live with to enable wonderful puzzles like this one. With one or two crossing letters, this answer came pretty quickly to me. This puzzle marks the 20th appearance of TEHEE in NYT CWP in the last 10 years: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Finder?w=TEHEE

@Bruce

 Make that "rise."

@Bill
Batik (a dyeing technique) uses a very densely woven cotton fabric, so you are mistaken about "cheap cotton batik," I'm thinking.  
I am very familiar with BATISTE, which is a lightweight, thin fabric (summer dresses, hankies, ruffles) that would never be used for batik.

I am abut to use some batiks that I created back in (ulp) 1978.  It was hell trying to get all of the wax out of the dense natural muslin fabric.
@Steve L   As a pre-Joe Namath NYTitans fan, not sure what Roman numerals have to do with ‚ÄòOver There‚Äô. It is a George M Cohen tune written in 1917. So Doughboy is the correct answer

Give it some thought.  

Then consider what the word "analogy" means.  And the concept of naming things retroactively.

And "doughboy" doesn't fit.

@Bob of Newton A friend of mine was very unhappy back in the 80s when he learned that though we were required to register for the draft, we would never be called "doughboys," as that was a term solely used for WWI soldiers.

Jane Wheelaghan,

Your question made me think about how I am often (irrationally) reluctant to ‚Äòcold-call‚Äô someone on their cell phone, since who knows where they are or what they‚Äôre doing (as opposed to just sitting home quietly, in the days of land lines). Anyway, I very often will text first, asking ‚ÄúYou okay for a call now?‚Äù  

So maybe now my text will be: ‚ÄúWatch for my new phone call, scheduled to drop in the next five minutes!!‚Äù
:)

@NYC Traveler
Thanks. I expect that still happens in very rural areas.

@Jane Wheelaghan

It happens on a parkway within 10 miles of here on a regular basis.  And this is roughly just 40 miles outside of New York City.  It's just an area within a large state park where they just missed installing the proper towers, and no one has done anything about.  It's a known issue, and people know not to initiate calls when heading into that area, and they warn people who've called them that the call will probably drop soon.
@JohnWM That's taking consideration for others to a whole new level üëå

And what a meshing of these two in that piece! Thank you for linking!

userLocation: Ridin' the big D of delight
commentBody:
@Bill

Rome rose for centuries. The Inca were masters of their realm for what? 150 years? The analogy with Tsarist Russia is more apt in this respect. Also, Romans let everybody assimilate, and in fact they incorporated foreign gods into their pantheon. Tsarist Russians had no tolerance for diversity whatsoever, as my 19th century ancestors would tell you - our language, culture and religion survived only because of their determination, despite Russian attempts at rooting it all out.

userLocation: Ridin' the big D of delight
commentBody:
@Bill

Russians didn't relocate people like the Assyrians (I am more familair with their example than with the Incan one) - they exiled opponents to Siberia, but it wasn't the same thing. Assyria (and maybe Inca?) relocated and dispersed whole populations of entire city-states - Russians exiled individuals who actively opposed them, to get rid of people who might become leaders of anti-Russian opposition. For example, after the failed Polish uprising of 1863-1964, many Polish nobles were sent to Siberia, as they were the local leaders whom people might want to follow into rebellion.
